questions.question: Identify the compound noun in the sentence: 'The basketball team won the championship.'
questions.explanation: 'Basketball' is a compound noun because it is made up of two words ('basket' and 'ball') combined to form a single noun.

questions.question: Choose the verb phrase in the sentence: 'They will be attending the conference next week.'
questions.explanation: 'Will be attending' is a verb phrase because it consists of multiple words that function together as the verb.

questions.question: Which word is the proper noun in the sentence: 'Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa.'
questions.explanation: 'Mount Kilimanjaro' is a proper noun as it names a specific mountain.

questions.question: Identify the proper noun in the sentence: 'Tesla was an innovator in the field of electricity.'
questions.explanation: 'Tesla' is a proper noun as it names a specific person.

questions.question: Which word is the transitive verb in the sentence: 'She mailed the letter yesterday.'
questions.explanation: 'Mailed' is a transitive verb because it requires an object ('letter') to complete its meaning.

questions.question: Identify the collective noun in the sentence: 'The jury delivered its verdict.'
questions.explanation: 'Jury' is a collective noun as it refers to a group of people chosen to make a decision.

questions.question: Choose the linking verb in the sentence: 'The cake tastes sweet and delicious.'
questions.explanation: 'Tastes' is a linking verb because it connects the subject ('cake') to the adjectives ('sweet' and 'delicious') describing it.

questions.question: Which word is the intransitive verb in the sentence: 'The leaves fell from the tree.'
questions.explanation: 'Fell' is an intransitive verb because it does not require an object to complete its meaning.

questions.question: Identify the abstract noun in the sentence: 'His bravery saved many lives.'
questions.explanation: 'Bravery' is an abstract noun as it represents an intangible quality.

questions.question: Which word is the gerund in the sentence: 'Hiking is a popular outdoor activity.'
questions.explanation: 'Hiking' is a gerund because it is a verb form ending in '-ing' that functions as a noun.

questions.question: Identify the compound noun in the sentence: 'She wore a handmade dress to the party.'
questions.explanation: 'Handmade' is a compound noun because it is made up of two words ('hand' and 'made') combined to form a single noun.

questions.question: Choose the verb phrase in the sentence: 'He has been reading the book all afternoon.'
questions.explanation: 'Has been reading' is a verb phrase because it consists of multiple words that function together as the verb.

questions.question: Which word is the proper noun in the sentence: 'The Nile River is the longest river in the world.'
questions.explanation: 'Nile River' is a proper noun as it names a specific river.

questions.question: Identify the proper noun in the sentence: 'Mozart composed many famous symphonies.'
questions.explanation: 'Mozart' is a proper noun as it names a specific person.

questions.question: Which word is the transitive verb in the sentence: 'He carried the suitcase upstairs.'
questions.explanation: 'Carried' is a transitive verb because it requires an object ('suitcase') to complete its meaning.

questions.question: Identify the collective noun in the sentence: 'The committee made a decision on the matter.'
questions.explanation: 'Committee' is a collective noun as it refers to a group of people appointed for a specific function.

questions.question: Choose the linking verb in the sentence: 'The roses smell wonderful in the garden.'
questions.explanation: 'Smell' is a linking verb because it connects the subject ('roses') to the adjective ('wonderful') describing it.

questions.question: Which word is the intransitive verb in the sentence: 'The stars twinkled in the night sky.'
questions.explanation: 'Twinkled' is an intransitive verb because it does not require an object to complete its meaning.

questions.question: Identify the abstract noun in the sentence: 'Freedom is a basic human right.'
questions.explanation: 'Freedom' is an abstract noun as it represents an intangible quality.

questions.question: Which word is the gerund in the sentence: 'Running is a good way to stay fit.'
questions.explanation: 'Running' is a gerund because it is a verb form ending in '-ing' that functions as a noun.

questions.question: Identify the compound noun in the sentence: 'My brother-in-law is visiting us this weekend.'
questions.explanation: 'Brother-in-law' is a compound noun because it is made up of multiple words combined to form a single noun.

questions.question: Choose the verb phrase in the sentence: 'They had been discussing the issue for hours.'
questions.explanation: 'Had been discussing' is a verb phrase because it consists of multiple words that function together as the verb.

questions.question: Which word is the proper noun in the sentence: 'The Grand Canyon is a popular tourist destination.'
questions.explanation: 'Grand Canyon' is a proper noun as it names a specific place.

questions.question: The last time I ________ to Korea, I spent three weeks in Cheju island.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'went' because it is the simple past tense form of the verb 'to go.' The sentence is referring to a specific past event when the speaker traveled to Korea, so the past tense is appropriate. The other options ('was going,' 'have gone,' and 'go') do not fit the context of the sentence.

questions.question: Bob ________ to Korea thirteen times.
questions.explanation: Bob has been to Korea thirteen times. This sentence is in the present perfect tense, which is used to describe an action that started in the past and is still ongoing or has just been completed. The phrase 'has been' is the correct form of the verb 'to be' in the present perfect tense when used with the subject 'Bob.' It indicates that Bob has visited Korea multiple times in the past and continues to do so.

questions.question: Before Jack arrived, Jill __________ up the hill.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'had already gone' because it indicates that Jill went up the hill before Jack arrived. The use of 'had' suggests that the action of going up the hill occurred in the past and is completed. 'Already' emphasizes that the action happened prior to Jack's arrival.

questions.question: It _________ everyday since I arrived here.
questions.explanation: The sentence is in the present perfect tense, which is used to talk about actions that started in the past and continue up to the present. The correct answer 'has rained' is in the present perfect tense, indicating that it has been raining continuously since the speaker arrived.

questions.question: The fans _________ when the game finally started.
questions.explanation: The verb 'cheered' is the correct answer because it is in the past tense and matches the subject 'fans.' This indicates that the fans were cheering at the specific time when the game finally started. The other options are either in the present tense ('cheers,' 'will cheer') or in the present perfect tense ('have cheered'), which do not accurately convey the past action of the fans cheering when the game started.

questions.question: By the time Sam pays off his student loan, he ____________ eighty years old.
questions.explanation: This question is testing the use of future tense. The phrase 'By the time Sam pays off his student loan' indicates a future event. Therefore, the correct answer is 'will be,' as it is the future tense form of the verb 'to be.' It suggests that by the time Sam finishes paying off his student loan, he will reach the age of eighty.

questions.question: By the time Bob gets back from the war, his daughter _________ from school.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'will have graduated.' This is because the sentence is talking about an action that will be completed in the future (Bob getting back from the war) in relation to another action that will also be completed in the future (his daughter graduating from school). The future perfect tense 'will have graduated' is used to indicate that the daughter's graduation will happen before Bob gets back from the war.

questions.question: Every time we ________ to that restaurant, my stomach gets upset.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'go.' The sentence is in present tense, so we need to use the base form of the verb. 'Go' is the base form of the verb 'to go,' which is the appropriate choice in this context.

questions.question: Everytime Max ________ help, he asks Mary.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'needs' because the sentence is in the present tense and 'needs' is the correct form of the verb 'need' for the third person singular subject 'Max'.

questions.question: Lightning ________rarely twice in the same place.
questions.explanation: Lightning strikes rarely twice in the same place. This sentence is in the present tense and the subject 'lightning' is singular. Therefore, the correct verb form to use is 'strikes.'

questions.question: He ________ met the school Director until he bumped into him in the supermarket this morning.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'had never.' This is because the sentence is in the past perfect tense, indicating an action that occurred before another past action. The phrase 'had never' indicates that the person had not met the school Director at any point in the past leading up to the moment in the supermarket this morning.

questions.question: Why did Max leave while we _________?
questions.explanation: Max left while we were talking because the action of talking was ongoing at the time Max decided to leave. The phrase 'were talking' indicates that the action was in progress in the past, suggesting that Max left during the conversation.

questions.question: The last time I ___________ to San Francisco, I saw somebody doing yoga naked along the wharf.
questions.explanation: The sentence is in the past tense and is referring to a specific incident that happened in the past. 'Went' is the correct answer because it is the past simple form of the verb 'go'. The other options ('have gone', 'go', 'was going') do not fit the context of the sentence as they do not indicate a completed action in the past.

questions.question: Steve ________ for the NSA before he quit.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'had worked'. This is because the sentence is in the past tense and indicates an action that occurred before another past action (Steve quitting). The past perfect tense 'had worked' is used to show that the action of working for the NSA was completed before Steve quit.

questions.question: George ________ his dog three times today. It's not even noon yet.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'has taken' because the sentence is referring to an action that George has performed multiple times in the past leading up to the present moment. The phrase 'three times today' indicates that the action of taking his dog has occurred on multiple occasions in the current day. The present perfect tense 'has taken' is used to describe an action that started in the past and has continued up until the present.

questions.question: John _________ the dogs for a walk before he fed them.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'took' because it is the past tense form of the verb 'take.' The sentence is referring to an action that happened in the past, specifically before John fed the dogs.

questions.question: Cinthia _________ doing yoga in the park very much until winter came.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'enjoyed.' The sentence is in past tense, indicated by the word 'until.' Therefore, the verb 'enjoyed' is the correct choice as it matches the past tense of the sentence. The other options, 'enjoys,' 'has enjoyed,' and 'will enjoy,' do not match the past tense of the sentence and are therefore incorrect.

questions.question: Christian __________ Betty for nearly two hours. I think he's about ready to give up.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'has been waiting'. This is because the sentence is in the present perfect continuous tense, which is used to describe an action that started in the past and is still ongoing. 'Has been waiting' indicates that Christian started waiting in the past and is still waiting at the present moment.

questions.question: I promised Jack that I _________ go to the hockey game with him on Friday.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'would' because it indicates a future intention or willingness to go to the hockey game with Jack on Friday.

questions.question: I painted the house and it ________ out better than I expected.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'turned'. In this sentence, the past tense of the verb 'turn' is required to match the past tense of the action of painting the house. The word 'turned' indicates that the outcome of painting the house was better than the speaker had expected.

questions.question: The test starts at 1:00pm. We ________ be back by that time.
questions.explanation: The word 'must' is the correct answer because it indicates a strong obligation or necessity. In this context, it implies that it is necessary for us to be back by 1:00pm. The other options, 'ought,' 'can,' and 'should,' do not convey the same level of obligation as 'must.'

questions.question: I _________ for a swim but I changed my mind.
questions.explanation: The sentence suggests that the speaker initially intended to not go for a swim, but then decided against it. The phrase 'wasn't going' accurately expresses this change of plans in the past tense.

questions.question: I don't remember _________ my computer.
options: For how long have I had
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'how long I've had' because the phrase 'how long I've had' is the correct way to ask about the duration of time someone has possessed or owned something, in this case, the computer. The other options are grammatically incorrect or do not convey the intended meaning.

questions.question: The weatherman says __________.
questions.explanation: The correct phrase is 'it will rain today.' This phrase uses the future tense, which is appropriate for weather forecasts. Weather predictions are about future events, so the weatherman uses the future tense ('will rain') to inform viewers about weather conditions expected to occur later on the same day.

questions.question: Andrew _________ the course on Javascript programming.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'has already taken'. This is because the sentence is in the present perfect tense, indicating an action that started in the past and is still relevant in the present. The verb 'has' is used with the subject 'Andrew' to show that he has completed the course on Javascript programming. The phrase 'already taken' further emphasizes that the action of taking the course occurred before now.

questions.question: _________ the new TV you bought?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'How big is'. This is the correct question structure to ask about the size of the new TV. The word 'how' is used to inquire about the extent or degree of something, in this case, the size. The word 'is' is the correct form of the verb 'to be' to use in this question.

questions.question: Randy was just going to bed when his wife _______ from work.
questions.explanation: Randy was just going to bed when his wife came home from work. This implies that Randy's wife arrived at their home after Randy had already started preparing to go to bed.

questions.question: I should _________ my books to school yesterday.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'have brought' because the sentence is in the past tense and requires the use of the present perfect tense. 'Have brought' is the correct form of the verb 'to bring' in the present perfect tense.

questions.question: Ronni, I _________ in a long time. How have you been?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'haven't seen' because it is the correct verb tense to use in this context. The sentence is in the present perfect tense, indicating that the action of not seeing Ronni has occurred in the past and is still ongoing in the present.

questions.question: Some people say that it is better to _________ for today.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'live' because the phrase 'for today' suggests that the action should be done in the present moment. 'Live' is the present tense form of the verb, indicating that it is the appropriate choice for the current time.

questions.question: Do you know the meaning of this word? No, but I can _______ in the dictionary.
questions.explanation: The phrase 'look it up' suggests that the person does not know the meaning of the word but can find it in the dictionary. This means they will search for the word's definition in a reference book or online resource to gain knowledge about its meaning.

questions.question: ________ your shoes before you step on the carpet.
questions.explanation: The phrase 'take off' means to remove or unfasten something, in this case, it refers to removing the shoes. The sentence is instructing someone to remove their shoes before stepping on the carpet.

questions.question: I read this book and ________ very interesting information.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'found out' because it implies discovering or learning something new or previously unknown. In the context of reading a book, 'found out' suggests that the reader came across interesting information while reading the book.

questions.question: It was very nice to meet you today. I am ______________ you again soon.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'looking forward to seeing' because the phrase 'looking forward to' is followed by a gerund (-ing form of a verb) to indicate anticipation or excitement about a future event. In this case, the speaker is expressing their excitement about seeing the person again in the future.

questions.question: Sam ________ when he was just 17, and since then, we haven't heard from him.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'ran away' because it implies that Sam left his home or a particular place without any intention of returning. This explains why no one has heard from him since he was 17. The other options, 'ran up,' 'ran down,' and 'run off,' do not convey the same meaning of leaving permanently or disappearing.

questions.question: A keystone to success is to never ________  on your dreams.
questions.explanation: The phrase 'give up' means to stop trying or to abandon something. In the context of the sentence, it suggests that one should never abandon or stop pursuing their dreams if they want to achieve success. This implies that perseverance and determination are essential qualities for achieving one's goals.

questions.question: We have a very tight schedule. We are ___________ you to get this job done in time.
questions.explanation: The phrase 'counting on' means to rely or depend on someone or something. In this context, the speaker is emphasizing that they have a tight schedule and they are relying on the person to get the job done in time.

questions.question: It takes a lot of intelligence to _______ of a prison.
questions.explanation: The phrase 'break out' is commonly used to describe the act of escaping or getting out of a prison. It implies using intelligence, planning, and cunning to successfully leave a confined space. 'Break down' means to lose control emotionally or mentally, 'break up' means to end a relationship or separate into smaller parts, and 'break in' means to forcefully enter a building or property. Therefore, 'break out' is the correct answer as it aligns with the context of escaping from a prison.

questions.question: I am sorry, I have to ___________ because I'm very busy right now.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'hang up.' This phrase is commonly used to indicate ending a phone call. In this context, the speaker is apologizing for having to end the call abruptly because they are busy.

questions.question: I didnt check the engine before we traveled, and the car ___________ in the middle of the road.
questions.explanation: If the engine of the car was not checked before the travel and it stopped working in the middle of the road, it means that the car 'broke down.' This phrase is commonly used to describe a vehicle that suddenly stops working or becomes inoperable. The other options, 'broke up,' 'broke in,' and 'break down,' do not accurately convey the situation of a malfunctioning engine in this context.

questions.question: An intransitive verb does not need a direct object.
questions.explanation: An intransitive verb is a verb that does not require a direct object to complete its meaning. It can stand alone and still make sense. Therefore, the statement 'an intransitive verb does not need a direct object' is true. In contrast, a transitive verb requires a direct object to complete its meaning.

questions.question: We would like to stay longer, but we must leave. Is the word leave transitive or intransitive?
questions.explanation: In this context, 'leave' is used as an intransitive verb because it does not require a direct object to complete its meaning. The action of leaving does not directly act upon anything or anyone. Intransitive verbs are verbs that do not need a direct object, whereas transitive verbs do. Here, 'leave' stands alone without needing further information, making it intransitive in this sentence.

questions.question: The audience attentively watched the latest production of The Trojan Women. Is the underlined word transitive or Intransitive?
questions.explanation: The verb 'watched' in the sentence 'The audience attentively watched the latest production of The Trojan Women' is a transitive verb. A transitive verb requires a direct object to complete its meaning. In this case, 'the latest production of The Trojan Women' is the direct object that receives the action of the verb 'watched.' Therefore, 'watched' is transitive.

questions.question: The crowd moves across the field in an attempt to see the rock star get into her helicopter. Is the verb transitive or intransitive? Hint - Read what the question is asking.
questions.explanation: The given sentence describes the movement of the crowd across the field to witness the rock star getting into her helicopter. The verb 'moves' does not require an object to complete its meaning, indicating that it is being used intransitively. Therefore, the correct answer is 'Intransitive.'

questions.question: A transitive verb is complete with a direct object. Is this true or false?
questions.explanation: A transitive verb is a verb that requires a direct object to complete its meaning. Without a direct object, the meaning of a transitive verb would be incomplete. In a sentence with a transitive verb, the action of the verb is transferred to or affects a direct object. Therefore, the statement 'A transitive verb is complete with a direct object' is true.

questions.question: "Great men are not always wise." What is the intransitive adjective in the sentence?
questions.explanation: In the sentence 'Great men are not always wise,' the word 'wise' is used as an adjective, describing a characteristic of the 'great men.' It is an intransitive adjective in this context. Adjectives are typically intransitive because they don't require a direct object to complete their meaning; they modify nouns or pronouns.

questions.question: The old man was extremely loveable. Extremely is the transitive verb. True or False?
questions.explanation: In the sentence 'The old man was extremely loveable,' the word 'extremely' is not a transitive verb. 'Extremely' is an adverb that modifies the adjective 'loveable.' Transitive verbs are action verbs that require a direct object to complete their meaning, and 'extremely' is not functioning as a verb in this sentence.

questions.question: Liz stayed an actress. What is the transitive verb?
options: Does not contain a transitive verb
questions.correctAnswer: Does not contain a transitive verb
questions.explanation: A transitive verb is one that requires a direct object to complete its meaning. In the sentence 'Liz stayed an actress,' the verb 'stayed' is an intransitive verb because it does not take a direct object; instead, it is followed by a subject complement ('an actress') that describes the subject 'Liz.' Therefore, there is no transitive verb in this sentence.

questions.question: Mary burned the toast. What is the direct object?
questions.explanation: The direct object in this sentence is 'toast' because it is the noun that receives the action of the verb 'burned.' Mary is the subject of the sentence and 'burned' is the verb, while 'toast' is the object that is directly affected by the action of burning.

questions.question: The teacher gave the students their test papers. Find the indirect object.
questions.explanation: In the sentence, the indirect object is the recipient of the direct object. The teacher (subject) performs the action (gave), and the direct object being transferred is 'test papers.' The entity receiving the direct object is 'the students,' making them the indirect object. The indirect object typically answers the question 'to whom?' or 'for whom?' the action of the verb is performed, which in this case is 'the students' receiving 'their test papers.'

questions.question: Which is the PAST SIMPLE FORM of the verb: TRY?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'Tried.' The past simple form of the verb 'try' is 'tried.' In English, when we want to talk about something that happened in the past, we often change the verb to its past simple form. So, in this case, 'tried' is the correct past simple form of 'try.'

questions.question: Which is the PAST SIMPLE FORM of: TO ASK?
questions.explanation: The past simple form of 'to ask' is 'asked.' In English, when we want to express an action that happened in the past, we use the past simple tense. In this case, 'asked' is the correct past simple form of the verb 'to ask.'

questions.question: I ________ to buy a pencil yesterday. I don't have pencils for today!
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'needed' because it is the past tense form of the verb 'need' which indicates a requirement or necessity. In the given sentence, the speaker is expressing that they had to buy a pencil yesterday because they did not have any pencils for today.

questions.question: I ________ sad when my mom left the house yesterday.
questions.explanation: The word 'felt' is the correct answer because it is the past tense of the verb 'feel.' In this sentence, the speaker is describing their emotions when their mom left the house yesterday. The word 'felt' indicates that the speaker experienced sadness at that time.

questions.question: Select the INFINITIVE FORM/PRESENT SIMPLE FORM of the PAST SIMPLE VERB: KEPT
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'Keep' because the question asks for the infinitive form or present simple form of the past simple verb 'kept.' 'Keep' is the base form of the verb, and it is used in the present tense.

questions.question: The PAST SIMPLE FORM of the verb LET is: LETED
questions.explanation: The correct answer is False because the past simple form of the verb 'let' is 'let' itself. There is no additional ending or suffix added to the verb in the past tense. Therefore, 'leted' is not the correct past simple form of 'let.'

questions.question: Which of these verbs are in PAST SIMPLE FORM?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is  Tried.' These verbs are in the past simple form because they indicate actions or states that occurred in the past. 'Tried' is the past simple form of 'try'.

questions.question: The PAST SIMPLE FORM of the verb PUT is: PUT
questions.explanation: The explanation for the given correct answer is that the past simple form of the verb 'put' is indeed 'put.' In English grammar, the past simple tense is used to talk about completed actions in the past. In this case, 'put' is both the base form and the past simple form of the verb, meaning it remains the same regardless of the tense. Therefore, the statement 'The PAST SIMPLE FORM of the verb PUT is: PUT' is true.

questions.question: Which is the INFINITIVE FORM/PRESENT SIMPLE FORM of the verb: MEANT?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'Mean.' The verb 'meant' is the past tense form of 'mean,' so the infinitive form or present simple form would be 'mean.'

questions.question: Which is the PAST SIMPLE FORM of the verb: GO?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'Went.' The past simple form of the verb 'go' is 'went.' In English, verbs often change forms to indicate the past tense. 'Went' is the correct past simple form of 'go.'

questions.question: Fill in the blanks with proper tense: Break broke ________
questions.explanation: The word 'break' is the base form of the verb, while 'broke' is the past tense form. The answer 'broken' is the past participle form of the verb 'break.' Past participles are used to form the perfect tenses and passive voice constructions. In this case, 'broken' is used to describe something that has been fractured or damaged in the past.

questions.question: Fill in the blanks with proper tense: Fall fell ______
questions.explanation: The verb 'fall' is in the past tense form 'fell'. In order to form the past participle of the verb, we add '-en' to the base form. Therefore, the correct past participle form of 'fall' is 'fallen'.

questions.question: Fill in the blanks with proper tense: See saw _______
questions.explanation: The word 'saw' is the past tense of the verb 'see.' In this sentence, the word 'seen' is the past participle form of the verb 'see.' It is used to indicate that the action of seeing has already happened. Since 'seen' is the correct past participle form of 'see' in this context, it is the correct answer.

questions.question: Fill in the blanks with proper tense: Take took ________
questions.explanation: The verb 'take' is irregular, and its past participle form is 'taken.' Therefore, in the sentence 'take took ________,' the correct answer is 'taken.'

questions.question: Fill in the blanks with proper tense: Have had ______
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'had.' This is because the phrase 'have had' is used to indicate an action that started in the past and is still ongoing or has recently ended. In this case, 'had' is the past tense form of the verb 'have,' which fits the context of the sentence.

questions.question: Fill in the blanks with proper tense: Be was/were  ______________
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'been.' In this question, we are looking for the correct past participle form of the verb 'be.' 'Been' is the past participle form of 'be,' which is used to form the perfect tenses in English.

questions.question: Fill in the blanks with proper tense: Write wrote  ______
questions.explanation: The word 'write' is in the past tense, and the word 'written' is also in the past tense. 'Write' and 'written' are forms of the same verb, with 'write' being the base form and 'written' being the past participle form. Therefore, 'written' is the correct answer as it matches the tense of the word 'write' in the sentence.

questions.question: Fill in the blanks with proper tense: Sleep slept ______
questions.explanation: The word 'slept' is the past tense form of the verb 'sleep'. In the given sentence, 'sleep' is already in the past tense, so we need to use the past tense form of the verb to maintain consistency. Therefore, 'slept' is the correct answer.

questions.question: Fill in the blanks with proper tense: Take took  _______________
questions.explanation: The verb 'take' is in the past tense, so the correct form of the verb to complete the sentence would also be in the past tense. 'Taken' is the past participle form of the verb 'take' and is the correct answer in this context.

questions.question: Fill in the blanks with proper tense: Lose lost _____
questions.explanation: The word 'lose' is the base form of the verb, while 'lost' is the past tense form. The blank space requires a word that is in the past tense to maintain grammatical consistency. 'Lost' is the correct answer as it fits the context of the sentence and completes the sentence structure.

questions.question: He ... 8 hours everyday.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'sleeps'. The verb 'sleeps' is the correct form to use with the pronoun 'he' in the present tense.

questions.question: She ... food in the supermarket
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'buys' because it is the correct form of the verb 'to buy' in the third person singular form. The subject 'she' is a singular pronoun, and when using the present tense in the third person singular, we add an -s to the verb. Therefore, 'buys' is the correct form.

questions.question: My mother ... a really tasty soup
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'cooks' because it is the present tense form of the verb 'cook' that agrees with the subject 'my mother'.

questions.question: He ... his car every week
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'washes'. The verb 'washes' agrees with the subject 'he' in the present tense. This indicates that the action of washing the car is performed by the person referred to as 'he' on a weekly basis.

questions.question: She never ... on the plane
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'flies' because it is the present tense form of the verb 'fly' when referring to a third-person singular subject, such as 'she.' The other options, 'flys' and 'flyes,' are not correct verb forms in standard English grammar.

questions.question: Where...................you yesterday ?
questions.explanation: The question is asking about the past, so the correct answer is 'were.' This is the past tense of the verb 'to be' used with the pronoun 'you.'

questions.question: I.....in Japan last month .
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'was.' This is because the sentence is in the past tense and the subject 'I' is singular, so the correct form of the verb 'to be' is 'was.'

questions.question: We.......in the school last February.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'were' because it agrees with the subject 'we' which is a plural pronoun. 'Was' would be used for a singular subject, 'are' for a present tense plural subject, and 'am' for a first person singular subject.

questions.question: My mom and my dad.......very happy when I was born.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'were' because the subject of the sentence is 'my mom and my dad,' which is plural. Therefore, the verb 'were' is used to agree with the plural subject and indicate that both parents were very happy when the speaker was born.

questions.question: He.........busy yesterday.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'was' because the sentence is referring to a singular subject 'he' and the past tense is being used to indicate that the person was busy yesterday.

questions.question: What is the third form of the verb fly?

questions.question: What is the V3 form of call?
questions.explanation: The V3 form of the verb 'call' is 'called.' This form indicates that the action of calling has already been completed.

questions.question: If you ______ (not / hurry) we ________ (be) late!
questions.explanation: This sentence is a conditional statement in the present tense. The correct answer is 'don't hurry / will' because it correctly matches the verb tense and form in the sentence.

questions.question: If he _____ (be) younger, he ________ (travel) more.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'were / would travel'. This is an example of the subjunctive mood used to express a hypothetical or unreal condition.

questions.question: If you ______ (have) a better job, you ________ (be) able to buy a new car
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'had / would be'. This is because the sentence is in the conditional type 2, which is used to talk about hypothetical or unreal situations in the present or future.

questions.question: If Julie _______ (not/wear) a hat, she _____(get) sunstroke.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'doesn't wear / gets'. This sentence is in the present simple tense, indicating a habitual action and its consequence.

questions.question: I ________ (get) promoted if I _________ (speak) fluent English.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'would get / spoke' because it follows the conditional structure of the sentence.

questions.question: If the weather __________ (not / improve), we _________ (not/have) a picnic
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'doesn't improve / won't have' because it indicates that if the weather does not get better, the picnic will not happen.

questions.question: We _________ (not / go) to the restaurant if you _________ (not / hungry).
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'won't go / are not hungry'. This is a conditional sentence indicating that if the person is not hungry, they will not go to the restaurant.

questions.question: I _______ (cycle) to work if the weather ______ (be) fine.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'will cycle / is'. The sentence is in the first conditional, where the action depends on a future condition.

questions.question: While she _________ (cook) they ________ (watch) TV
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'was cooking / were watching'. This sentence is in the past continuous tense, indicating ongoing actions in the past.

questions.question: They ________ (dance) when Pedro ______ (fall) off.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'were dancing / fell.' This is because the sentence is in the past continuous tense, indicating ongoing action, and simple past tense for a single completed action.

questions.question: My car is____________________(expensive)yours.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'more expensive than' because it is used to compare the cost of two cars. It indicates that the speaker's car has a higher price than the listener's car.

questions.question: This restaurant is____________________(cheap)the other one we went last week.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'cheaper than' because it is used to compare the prices of two restaurants. It indicates that this restaurant has lower prices compared to the one they went to last week.

questions.question: Madonna is____________________(old)Britney Spears.
questions.explanation: Madonna is described as 'older than' Britney Spears, indicating that Madonna is of a higher age than Britney Spears.

questions.question: You drive____________________(fast)Paolo does.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is 'faster than' because it completes the comparison between the speaker's driving speed and Paolo's driving speed. It indicates that the speaker's driving speed is greater than Paolo's driving speed.

questions.question: This box is____________________(heavy)that other one.
questions.explanation: The given correct answer 'heavier than' is appropriate because it completes the comparison between two boxes. It indicates that the subject box carries more weight than the other box.

questions.question: This book is____________________(good)the other one the teacher asked us to read last semester.
questions.explanation: The given correct answer is 'better than'. This indicates that 'this book' is of higher quality or more favorable compared to 'the other one' that the teacher asked the students to read last semester.

questions.question: My boss is____________________(busy)today than he was yesterday.
questions.explanation: 'Busier' is the comparative form of 'busy'. It compares the level of busyness between two different time periods, indicating that the boss is more busy today than he was yesterday.

questions.question: He is____________________(cute)boy I've ever seen in my life.

questions.question: Which word is the proper noun in the sentence: 'The Amazon River flows through several countries in South America.'
questions.explanation: 'Amazon River' is a proper noun as it names a specific geographical feature.

questions.question: Identify the abstract noun in the sentence: 'Her kindness touched everyone's heart.'
questions.explanation: 'Kindness' is an abstract noun as it represents an intangible quality.

questions.question: Which word is the transitive verb in the sentence: 'The writer crafted an intriguing story.'
questions.explanation: 'Crafted' is a transitive verb because it requires an object ('story') to complete its meaning.

questions.question: Identify the proper noun in the sentence: 'The Taj Mahal is a wonder of the world.'
questions.explanation: 'Taj Mahal' is a proper noun as it names a specific monument.

questions.question: Choose the verb phrase in the sentence: 'They should have known about the changes.'
questions.explanation: 'Should have known' is a verb phrase because it consists of multiple words that function together as the verb.

questions.question: Identify the collective noun in the sentence: 'A team of researchers conducted the study.'
questions.explanation: 'Team' is a collective noun as it refers to a group of individuals working together.

questions.question: Which word is the intransitive verb in the sentence: 'The cat purred softly as it slept.'
questions.explanation: 'Purred' is an intransitive verb because it does not require an object to complete its meaning.

questions.question: Identify the compound noun in the sentence: 'The playground was filled with laughter.'
questions.explanation: 'Playground' is a compound noun because it is made up of two words ('play' and 'ground') combined to form a single noun.

questions.question: Choose the linking verb in the sentence: 'The idea seems brilliant.'
questions.explanation: 'Seems' is a linking verb because it connects the subject ('idea') to the adjective ('brilliant') describing it.

questions.question: Identify the gerund in the sentence: 'Cooking requires patience and precision.'
questions.explanation: 'Cooking' is a gerund because it is a verb form ending in '-ing' that functions as a noun.

questions.question: Which word is the proper noun in the sentence: 'The Nile River is the longest river in the world.'
questions.explanation: 'Nile River' is a proper noun as it names a specific geographical feature.

questions.question: Identify the abstract noun in the sentence: 'Her determination led to her success.'
questions.explanation: 'Determination' is an abstract noun as it represents an intangible quality.

questions.question: Which word is the transitive verb in the sentence: 'The mechanic fixed the car quickly.'
questions.explanation: 'Fixed' is a transitive verb because it requires an object ('car') to complete its meaning.

questions.question: Identify the proper noun in the sentence: 'The Mona Lisa is an iconic painting.'
questions.explanation: 'Mona Lisa' is a proper noun as it names a specific painting.

questions.question: Choose the verb phrase in the sentence: 'He might have forgotten his keys at home.'
questions.explanation: 'Might have forgotten' is a verb phrase because it consists of multiple words that function together as the verb.

questions.question: Identify the collective noun in the sentence: 'The committee reached a unanimous decision.'
questions.explanation: 'Committee' is a collective noun as it refers to a group of people making a decision together.

questions.question: Which word is the intransitive verb in the sentence: 'The stars twinkled in the night sky.'
questions.explanation: 'Twinkled' is an intransitive verb because it does not require an object to complete its meaning.

questions.question: Identify the compound noun in the sentence: 'She placed the bookshelf against the wall.'
questions.explanation: 'Bookshelf' is a compound noun because it is made up of two words ('book' and 'shelf') combined to form a single noun.

questions.question: Choose the linking verb in the sentence: 'The flowers smell wonderful in the garden.'
questions.explanation: 'Smell' is a linking verb because it connects the subject ('flowers') to the adjective ('wonderful') describing it.

questions.question: Identify the gerund in the sentence: 'Dancing brings her a lot of joy.'
questions.explanation: 'Dancing' is a gerund because it is a verb form ending in '-ing' that functions as a noun.

questions.question: Which word is the proper noun in the sentence: 'The Pacific Ocean is the largest ocean on Earth.'
questions.explanation: 'Pacific Ocean' is a proper noun as it names a specific geographical feature.
